Remediation performance and mechanism of hexavalent chromium in alkaline soil using multi-layer loaded nano-zero-valent iron٭

a b s t r a c t
Remediation of soil chromium (Cr) pollution is becoming more and more urgent. In this study, a multiloaded nano-zero-valent iron (nZVI) material (CNH) was prepared by carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) and humic acid (HA) as dispersant and support agent, respectively, and the remediation effect of CNH, HA and CN (CNH without HA) for Cr contaminated soil was investigated within 90 d cycle. After 7 d treatment of CNH, the HOAc-extractable Cr decreased significantly. After the 90 d remediation, the HOAc-extractable Cr decreased most in the treatment of 3% CNH, about 74.48% lower than control. All treatments eventually caused different decline of soil pH, with a range of 0.12e0.54, in which the CNH treatment group had the least depression. HA loading significantly weakened the toxicity of nZVI, resulting in the higher soil microbial quantity and enzyme activities compared with CN. Additionally, the improvement of soil microecology by CNH and HA was positively correlated with the ratio of application, while CN was negatively correlated (except FDA enzyme activity) with these indexes. These results emphasized the potential of the synthesized CNH as a promising material to remediate Cr contaminated soil. Furthermore, details of possible mechanistic insight into the Cr remediation were carefully discussed.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Soil heavy metal pollution has become an eye-catching environmental issue that seriously threatened ecological environment safety (Zhai et al., 2018). Due to various industrial activities such as mining, leather tanning, textile, metallurgical (Vilardi et al., 2019b) and electroplating, Cr (VI) was released in large quantities into the soil. China soil pollution bulletin (2014) published that the national soil Cr pollution point exceeded the standard by 1.1%. Some research (Zhang et al., 2016) has demonstrated that the average Cr concentration (78.94mg/kg) in chinawas 1.38 times higher than its background concentration and 1.26% of arable land was at risk of high Cr pollution, some areas were even as high as 3353.60mg/kg. Cr (VI) has been listed as an “A” carcinogen by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and is usually found in soil in the form of CrO42 , Cr2O72 and HCrO4 , which are not easy to be remediated but easy to be eluted into groundwater or captured by plants
e by Bernd Nowack.
ork and should be considered
(Arshad et al., 2017; Dhal et al., 2013; Maqbool et al., 2015). Cr (III), mainly exists in forms of Cr3þ, Cr(OH)2þ, Cr(OH)2þ and Cr(OH)3, is less bioavailable than Cr (VI) and is easily adsorbed or precipitated by soil colloid (Gilcardeza et al., 2014). Therefore, the treatment of Cr (VI) pollution has attracted a growing number of attention and became a high-profile issue.
Up to now, several approaches including bioremediation (e.g. resistant bacteria, plant enrichment), physical remediation (e.g. surface capping, encapsulation, and landfilling), chemical remediation (e.g. soil flushing, immobilization) (Liu et al., 2018) or away of combining them have been developed to remediate Cr contamination, among which bioremediation was environment-friendly and cost involved. However, time-consuming and instability of remediate results limited the practical application of the technology. Physical remediation technology was mature and effective for high pollution, but it often required a lot of manpower and resources (Khalid et al., 2016). Reducing Cr (VI) to Cr (III) was a desirable remediate idea in Cr contaminated soil (Giorgio Vilardi*, 2017; Mouhamadou Thierno Gueyea, 2016). Chemical remediation could finish just that quickly. In recent years, as a kind of chemical material, nano-zero-valent iron (nZVI) has become a very active research field in environmental pollution remediation (Jiang et al., 2018). Themechanism of oxidation-reduction reaction between Fe0
and Cr6þ causes Cr (VI) to be reduced to Cr (III), previous study has also demonstrated that the particle-gain model was the mechanism by which nZVI works (Vilardi et al., 2019a).
Nevertheless, easy agglomeration, poor air stability, difficulty in recycling and its some degree of ecological toxicity (Liang et al., 2017), all these shortcomings hinder nZVI to further exert remediation strength (Ren et al., 2018; Wu et al., 2018b). Various materials were employed to inhibit this phenomenon (Yang et al., 2018). Previous study (Vilardi et al., 2018b; Vilardi et al., 2019b) developed a material which utilized olive stone coated with nZVI and nano-magnetite, with a Cr removal efficiency about 70%. With good pore structure, biochar was also often used to modify nZVI (Su et al., 2016). In addition, humic acid (HA), an important material for heavy metal contaminated soil remediation, can effectively react with heavy metals through various mechanisms including adsorption, chelating and redox reactions due to the structural framework of HA itself and its rich functional groups, such as aromatic rings, conjugated double bonds, eOH, eCOOH etc. (Clemente and Bernal, 2006). The large specific surface area leads applying HA to reduce nZVI polymerization degree feasible. As we known, HA loaded nZVI as a composite material to remediate heavy metal contaminated soil was less reported. Moreover, the addition of some surfactants such as environment-friendly carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) could eliminate the inhibition that HA could occupy the reactive sites of nZVI, thereby inhibiting the removal of contaminants as some literature indicated (Dong and Lo, 2013; Qian et al., 2011; Zhang et al., 2008). Therefore, the multilayer modified nZVI (CNH) with nZVI as core, HA layer as carrier and CMC layer as dispersant may have better ability to immobilize Cr.
Consequently, we have prepared a multi-layer modified nZVI material (CNH) to remediate Cr contaminated soil. And the CN particle (nZVI was only modified by CMC) was also prepared to compare the differences between CN and CNH. The characteristics of the materials were determined by scanning electron microscope (SEM), energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and X-ray diffraction (XRD). In addition, soil pH, enzyme activities, microbial counts and Cr fractions were detected to evaluate remediation efficiency.

sections.heading: 2.1. Soil preparation
sections.text: The original soil sample (without Cr) was obtained from an abandoned land in Sichuan University, Chengdu, China. Then the soil was sieved with a 0.2mm standard griddle, air dried andmixed with K2Cr2O7 solution. Thereafter, the soil was aged for 3 months for subsequent experiments (mixing and aging method was reported in supplementary materials). The final Crtotal in soil was 110mg/kg by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) method 3050 B (1996). Main properties of this soil were shown in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.2. Material synthesis and characterization
sections.text:
The HA used in this experiment was purchased from Chengdu Kelong Corp (China). Main characteristics of HA were illustrated in Table 1. The synthesis procedure of the nano-materials applied in this research was ameliorated by previous methods (Shariatmadari et al., 2009; Wang et al., 2017). Briefly, 5 g HA was added into 150mL 0.1% CMC solution and sonicated for 1 h, 0.27M FeSO4 7H2O was transferred into the above solution and shaken at 150 rpm 25 C for 24 h. The mixture was then poured into a 1 L three-necked flask and nitrogen was continuously purged to remove oxygen. Next, 500mL 0.5M NaBH4 was added dropwise at
10mLmin 1 rate. The obtained CNHwas dried in a vacuum oven at 50 C. CN particle was prepared by using the samemethod as above without HA.
SEM (JSM-7500 F) coupled with EDS (AXIS Ultra DLD) were used to figure out the surface morphology and obtain surface elemental distribution maps of the prepared materials. XRD (EMPYREAN) patterns were implemented on a D/Max-IIIA powder X-ray diffractometer using filtered Cu Ka radiation to clarify the crystallization of the materials. Surface functional groups of the samples were measured by FTIR (Nicolet 6700).

sections.heading: 2.3. Experimental design
sections.text: Experiments were conducted in plastic pots (base: 9 cm; height: 11 cm; caliber 14 cm) containing 1 kg of contaminated soil. Multiple experimental treatments were carried out in this study. The final dosage of the material was 1.5% (15mg g 1) and 3% (30mg g 1) of the soil weight according to the preliminary experiments results (Table S1). The different treatments were T0 (control), T1 (1.5% CNH), T2 (3% CNH), T3 (1.5% HA), T4 (3% HA), T5 (1.5% CN), T6 (3% CN) with three repetitions. The right amount of unified ultrapure water was added to these treatments to ensure that the soil water holding capacity was maintained at around 60%. Changes of the corresponding soil biochemical indicators were determined on the 7th, 14th, 30th, 50th and 90th d, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.4.1. Soil microbial quantity
sections.text: The soil microbial counts were determined through the method proposed by previous study (Cheema et al., 2009; Vieira and Nahas, 2005). 3 g soil samples were thoroughly mixed in 20mL ultrapure sterile water, then counted on beef extract peptone medium (bacteria) and PDA medium (fungi) with the dilution of 10 6 and 10 4, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Soil enzyme analysis and soil pH measurement
sections.text:
The determination of soil pHwas carried out in a soil suspension (1: 9 of soil: water (w: w)) (Sumner, 1994). Invertase, acid phosphatase, urease and fluorescein diacetate (FDA) hydrolase were assayed in this study. Urease activity was determined by the method of sodium phenolate colorimetry at 578 nm (Kandeler and Gerber, 1988; Yan et al., 2013), which expressed urease activity as mg NH4þ g 1 h 1. The determination of invertase was based on 3,5- dinitrosalicylic acid colorimetric method at 508 nm (Gu et al., 2009), which defined the invertase activity as mg glucose g 1 h 1. Acid phosphatase activity was detected with the method
(Izaguirre-Mayoral et al., 2002). It was measured at 420 nm and was defined as m pNP g 1. FDA hydrolase activity was assayed with the method (Dick et al., 1996). It was measured at 490 nm and expressed as mg fluorescein g 1. The detailed determination methods were placed in the supplementary material.

sections.heading: 2.5. Sequential extraction of Cr
sections.text:
The BCR sequential extraction method was utilized to extract the four fractions of Cr: HOAc-extractable, reducible, oxidizable and residual fractions (Ciba et al., 2003; Golia et al., 2007; Rauret et al., 2000).
1 g soil and 40mL 0.11M HOAc (pH 2.8) solution were added into a 100mL centrifuge tube and shaken for 16 h (HOAc-extractable), the residue was further shakenwith 40mL 0.5M NH2OH$HCl for 16 h (reducible), the residue from the second step was digested with 30% H2O2 in awater bath at 85 C, and then shakenwith 40mL 1M NH4Ac for 16 h (pH¼ 2) (oxidizable). Air-dried residue (0.1 g), eventually, was finally fully digested in a 50mL crucible according to the requirements of the national standard (HJ 781e2016) on a hot plate with the mixed solution of HNO3: HF: HClO4 (5: 5: 3, v/v/v) (residual). The first three steps were performed in a 250 rpm, 37 C constant temperature shaker. Each tube was centrifuged at 3500 rpm for 20min after shaking, the supernatant was filtered to be analyzed and the residue was reserved for the next step. Flame atomic absorption spectrophotometry (FAAS) (Thermo, ICE 3000) was utilized to ascertain the content of Cr.

sections.heading: 2.6. Data analysis
sections.text: Mean and standard deviation values of three replicates were calculated in this study. Statistical significance was performed using SPSS 18.0 package. Comparisons of means were carried out using least significant differences (LSD) at a significance level of P< 0.05. All statistics were plotted using the Origin 8.0 (USA).

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of materials
sections.text: SEM accompanied with EDS verified the morphological characterization of CN and CNH. Fig. 1a and b showed that CN particles tended to form aggregated flocs, the more dispersed structure of CNH indicated that HA could indeed relieve the agglomeration of CN. Fig. S1a-b corroborated the existence of iron in the scanned area. FTIR was manipulated to assess changes of related groups that HA brought to CNH (Fig. S1c). An obvious increase in the wavelength of 617.01 cm 1 was obtained, which could attribute to the stretching of -C-O. Partial offset occurred in 1106.60 cm 1, indicating that the content of fatty ether (-C-O-C) significantly increased. The wavelength at 1638 cm 1 roughly corresponded to eC]O (Dong et al., 2017b). In addition, a broad and strong peak appeared near 3371.57 cm 1 approximately relevant to eaOH (Wu et al., 2018a), which predicting that changes of intermolecular hydrogen bonds on the surface of CNH. Above all, the increased groups especially oxygen-containing functional groups contributed profoundly to the adsorption capacity of CNH (Zhang et al., 2018a). The characteristic diffraction peak around 44.6 of XRD patterns (Fig. S1d) in CN and CNH declared successful synthesis of Fe0.

sections.heading: 3.2. Immobilization effects of materials on soil Cr
3.2.1. HOAc-extractable Cr changes in soil
sections.text:
Ecosystem would suffer varying degrees of damage due to the occurrences of different fractions of the same heavy metal.
Compared with the total amount of heavy metal, the toxicity effects could be more clearly reflected by the HOAc-extractable fraction of heavy metal (Allen et al., 1980; Dang and Obbard, 2006; Ma et al., 2016; Peijnenburg and Jager, 2003). The changes of HOAcextractable Cr during processing were presented in Fig. 2a. After 14 d of treatment, compared with all of the other treatments, 3% CN treatment reduced the HOAc-extractable Cr the most, which decreased 73.46% of control. Meanwhile, in 3% CNH and 3% HA treatment, the HOAc-extractable Cr declined 71.63% and 31.29% of control, respectively. That is, in thefirst twoweeks, CNshowedbetter Cr passivation ability than CNH and HA, which may ascribe to the slower aggregation of nZVI with the presence of CMC. CN had more iron reaction site than CNH, so faster Cr passivation ability was observed in the short term. Compared with d 14, the HOAcextractable Cr in all iron-based treatments increased on d 30, and the increase of CN treatment was more serious than that of CNH treatment. Previous research interpreted that the increase mainly due to the conversion of some unstable Cr and the release of part of the precipitation products slightly adsorbed on the soil substrate (Palma et al., 2015), indicating the modification of nZVI by CMC and HA, especially HA, effectively alleviated the activation of Cr in soil. Finally, the immobilizing rates of 1.5% CNH, 3% CNH, 1.5% CN, 3% CN treatment were 72.85%, 74.86%, 69.16%, 63.99%, respectively. On the 90th d, the HOAc-extractable Cr of 3% CN treatment increased and its passivation rate decreased, this may due to in the later stage of passivation, 3% CN released more Fe3þ than 1.5% CN, in alkaline condition, Fe3þ consumedOH in soil and thus formedmore Fe(OH)3 deposited on the surface of 3% CN particles, thus forming a denser
passivation layer, causing its “aging”, its shell thickness, void size and the composition changing (Jiang et al., 2018), which hindered the reaction between the internal Fe0 and Cr (VI) in soil (Gan et al., 2019; Zhu et al., 2016) and might result in the re-dissociation of Cr which had previously loosely bound on the surface of 3% CN particles. Such phenomenon did not occur in 3% CNH treatment, indicating the loading of HA could not only improve the passivation efficiency, but also prevent the formation of such a dense passivation layer.
To evaluate whether CNH could still maintain stable Cr passivation ability in long-term condition, BCR sequential extraction experiments were carried out again on the 240th d. As shown in Fig. S2a, HOAc-extractable Cr in 3% CNH treatment did not fluctuate significantly between the 7th d and the 240th d, suggesting that CNH treatment has reached repair equilibrium within 90 d and could maintain for a long time.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Cr species distribution analysis
sections.text:
After 90 d treatment, the BCR sequential extraction method was
exerted to determine the species transformation of Cr in soil. The results were exhibited in Fig. 2b. The percentages of the four species in control were 15.96% HOAc-extractable, 5.79% reducible, 32.74% oxidizable and 45.51% residual, respectively. Compared with control, significant cutbacks in HOAc-extractable and increments in residual were observed in all treatments. Especially in 3% CNH treatment, the percentages of HOAc-extractable and residual were 5.06% and 50.05%, which were the lowest and highest values among all treatments, respectively. It illustrated that among all treatments, 3% CNH treatment maximized the transformation of the most unstable HOAc-extractable Cr into the other three more stable forms, thereby achieving better heavy metal immobilization and attenuation. Besides, the oxidizable Cr of 3% HA treatment had the maximal increase compared with other treatments, which was 29.72% higher than control. This may attribute to the rich functional groups of HA, such as carboxyl, phenol, hydroxyl, enol and carbonyl structures (Aiken et al., 1985). They formed complexes with Cr through the reactions of functional groups and coordination bonds. Nevertheless, the adsorption capacity of HA was not as superior as that of CNH, therefore, the reaction of HAwith Cr mainly raised the oxidizable Cr and a small part of the residual Cr.
From Fig. S2b, the residual Cr of 3% CNH treatment was still the highest among all treatments, followed by 1.5% CNH treatment, which indicated that the Cr fractions in CNH treatment were still more stable than that of CN treatment group within 240 d and its passivation ability to Cr was stable even under long-term conditions.

sections.heading: 3.3. Change of soil pH by materials treatment
sections.text:
pH is also an important parameter for evaluate the effect of nZVI on the transfer behavior of Cr in soil (Vítkov a et al., 2017). Fig. 3 revealed the changes of soil pH throughout 90 d. It could infer that the soil showed obvious alkalinity. After 7 d treatment, the pH of all treatments decreased slightly compared with control. Owing to the fact that HA itself was acidic, it caused the soil pH to drop the most, about 0.2 points. nZVI served as a strong reductant, which reduced Cr (VI) to Cr (III), and ultimately released Hþ into the soil (Burris et al., 1995; Gheju, 2011). Except HA, the pH decreased most in 3% CN treatment, which proved that there were more reaction sites in CN than CNH in the early reaction. The ultimate reaction
equation was as follow (Zhang et al., 2012):
xCr3þ þ (1-x)Fe3þ þ 3H20 / Cr x Fe(1-x) (OH)3Yþ 3Hþ
In aerobic condition, Fe (II), produced by the oxidization of Fe0, consumed Hþ to be oxidized to Fe (III) (Vítkov a et al., 2017), so the soil pH increased slightly from 14th to 30th d. Furthermore, the ascent of pH meant lower Eh. Lower redox potential promoted reduction reaction later (Aharonov-Nadborny et al., 2018), implying that more Cr (Ⅵ) may be reduced to Cr (III). Therefore, the HOAcextractable of 1.5% CNH, 3% CNH, 3% CN, 1.5% CN treatment decreased again after 30 d. On the 90th d, 3%/1.5% CNH, 3%/1.5% HA, 3%/1.5% CN depressed the initial soil pH by about 0.18/0.12, 0.54/ 0.39, 0.29/0.21 points comparedwith T0, respectively.What's more, soil pH no longer showed a downward trend on d 240 as Fig. S3 demonstrated. Among all treatments, 3% CNH treatment recovered to closest to natural soil pH, which elaborated that CNH not only had prominent Cr passivation ability, but also could minimize the disturbance received by soil.

sections.heading: 3.4. Response of soil microecology to materials processing
3.4.1. Comparison of microbial counts
sections.text:
Microorganisms act as vital resources in soil for facilitating plant growth, improving soil quality and accelerating the remediation of contaminated soil. Soil microbes are sensitive indicators of soil quality (Wang et al., 2018). Remarkable ascents in all groups were heeded after 90 d as demonstrated by Fig. 4a. The maximum bacteria and fungi counts both emerged in T4 due to the rich nutrients of HA (Maji et al., 2016), followed by 3% CNH treatment, about 345.67% and 436% of control respectively. Whereas just 175.59% (bacteria) and 188% (fungi) were augmented in 3% CN treatment compared with control. 1.5% CNH and 1.5% CN had similar effects on fungi, while the bacteria count of 1.5% CNH treatment was 1.39 times of that in 1.5% CN treatment. It indicated that CNH could improve the micro-ecological environment of the remediated soil better than other iron-based materials.
To further reflect the changes of microecology, four important enzyme activities (invertase, urease, acid phosphatase, FDA hydrolase) were determined. The four enzymes selected in this study could reflect stress of the soil (Li et al., 2018), they are closely related to soil organic matter content, soil nitrogen and phosphorus cycling, soil total enzyme level respectively (Chernysheva et al., 2015; Ge et al., 2011; Schnürer and Rosswall, 1982). The results were described in Fig. 4bee. Due to the toxicity of CN and CNH itself and the fact that the toxicity of soil Cr was still intense initially, the enzyme activities (except FDA hydrolase) in iron-based materials treatments (T1, T2, T5, T6) showed significantly lower than control within 14 d. From the downward trend of these enzyme activities (except FDA enzyme activity), we could deduce that the general toxicity trend was 3% CN> 1.5% CNz 3% CNH> 1.5% CNH. The overall trend of the four enzymes indicated that HA greatly stimulated the increments of soil enzyme activities.
The enzyme activities of all groups were gradually higher than T0 as time extended from 7th to the 90th d. The trends of FDA hydrolase, urease and invertase activities were roughly similar, in which 3% HA treatment finally presented the maximum enzyme activities and 3% CNH treatment just lower than it, or even higher than it in invertase. Taking invertase as an example, the highest invertase activity was observed in 3% CNH treatment after 90 d, which was approximately 168.64% of control. While 3% HA treatment was just 122.71% of control. What's more, similar with the BCR results, the enzyme activities (except FDA) of T6 were even lower than T5. The reason why the aforementioned phenomena didn't emerge in FDA hydrolase may be that the enzyme was less
sensitive to the toxicity of nZVI/Cr and depended more on the total amount of soil microorganisms (Coppolecchia et al., 2011). These results explicated that CNH was more conducive to alleviate soil Cr stress than CN and the loading of HAweakened the toxicity of nZVI.
The soil acid phosphatase activity was some difference compared with the other three enzymes. That is, the enzyme activity of CNH treatment was no longer higher than that of CN treatment. Sharp raising was observed in CN treatment on the 50th to 90th d, the final 1.5% CN and 3% CN were 1.27 and 1.21 times of the corresponding 1.5% CNH and 3% CNH, respectively. The result was relevant to the soil pH. During the period of 50th-90th d, the activity of acid phosphatase in CN treatments increased with the corresponding pH decreased, intimating that the acid phosphatase was mostly dependent on the soil pH (Rojo et al., 1990). On the other hand, it was possible that the application of CN stimulated the conversion of phosphatase-related microorganisms (Li et al., 2017).
The microbial counts and soil enzyme activities of uncontaminated soil (natural soil) and all treatments’ soil after 90 d were compared to explore the immobilization effect, the results were shown in Fig. S4. Obviously, except for urease, the other three enzyme activities level and the soil microbial level was comparable to uncontaminated soil in all treatments, among which 3% CNH and 3% HA treatments had almost the highest levels. Although only HA treatments showed higher urease activity than that in uncontaminated soil, the 3% CNH treatment still exhibited the highest urease activity among all the iron-based material treatments. The above results elaborated that HA has almost completely improved soil micro-ecology, followed by CNH. Combined with the results of BCR, CNH was superior to rehabilitate soil state.

sections.heading: 3.5. Remediation mechanism of materials
sections.text:
Cr treated by nanomaterials, reduction and adsorption were deemed as the main patterns (Vilardi et al., 2018a). Alkaline soils, owing to its high OH , highly corrode the surface of nano-iron particles, and there was deficient in Hþ to eliminate this corrosion. Previous study (Noubactep, 2008; Zhu et al., 2017) suggested that acidic conditions were more favorable for the reduction of Cr by nZVI and others also stated that under alkaline condition, the remediation mechanism of Cr treated by nZVI was mainly indirect homogenization (Ambika and Nambi, 2016). The changes of HOAcextractable Cr in all treatments manifested that CNH exhibited preeminent remediation effect throughout the period, while CN performed remediation weakness after 30 d. The difference between CNH and CN lay in that CNH had the surface area provided by HA for its dispersion and the chelating ability provided by the functional groups of HA. Therefore, in the condition that the alkaline condition was not conducive to the reduction ability of nZVI, we could infer that the initiation (0e30 d) mainly relied reduction to immobilize Cr, but complexation became the protagonist of remediation in 30e90 d. The remediation mechanism of CNH throughout the 90 d period was designated in Fig. 5.
Cr remediation by CNH mainly included the following steps (Diao et al., 2018; Kumari et al., 2015):
CrO42 þ Fe0 þ 8Hþ /Fe3þ þ Cr3þ þ 4H2O (1)
(1-x)Fe3þ þ xCr3þ þ 2H2O / Fe(1-x)Cr x OOH þ 3Hþ (2)
2≡FeeOH þ CrO42 / (≡ Fe-)2CrO4 þ 2OH (3)
In the late stage of remediation, the active site of iron nanoparticle gradually saturated, the surface was covered by precipitates, and it almost polymerized entirely. Therefore, the functional group sites provided by HA for CNH became the main
driving forces for later complexation (4) (5) (6) (Aiken et al., 1985; Wang et al., 2010), for example, eOH and other polar groups (Chen et al., 2011) could be used as an electron donor for Cr (VI) reduction (Zhang et al., 2018b), eCOOH and eC]O mainly participated in Cr complexation (Huang et al., 2012). Meanwhile, HA could reduce part of Fe3þ to Fe2þ (Mak and Lo, 2011; Tang et al., 2014), which impeded the precipitation of Fe3þ, thereupon, the partial recycling of nZVI realized (7) (8) (9) (10) (Anhuai Lu et al., 2006; Dong et al., 2017a):
3ReCOOH þ Cr3þ / (ReCOO)3Cr þ 3Hþ (4)
CrO42 þ 2Hþ þ ReOH / ReOCrO3H þ H2O (5)
ReC]O þ HCrO4 / ReC]O…HOCrO3 (6)
Fe3þ þ HA/Fe2þ þ Fe-HA (7)
2CrO42 þ 3Fe2þ þ 8Hþ / 2Cr3þ þ 3Fe3þ þ 4H2O (8)
3Fe2þ þ CrO42 þ 4OH þ 4H2O¼ 3Fe (OH)3 þ Cr (OH)3 (9)
6Fe2þ þ CrO42 þ 13OH ¼ 3Fe2O3 þ Cr (OH)3 þ 5H2O (10)
Soil microecology could be stimulated by the materials applied, in turn, it could also promote the function of materials. Previous study has dug out that microorganism in soil could also react with Cr (VI) through various pathways, such as: secreting chelates (Desjardin et al., 2002), bioreduction (Wu et al., 2019), bioaccumulation (Banerjee et al., 2019). As illustrated in Fig. 4, soil microorganism count and enzyme activities have been significantly upgraded in CNH treatments, these gradually active microbial activities might invigorate its remediation effect.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The remediation effects of CNH, CN, HA and their different concentrations on Cr contaminated soil were investigated. It was verified that CMC and HA significantly amplified the stability of nZVI and further enhanced the remediation performance. Remediate process was balanced within 90 d, the highest Cr passivation rate was 74.48% in the 3% CNH treatment, and the Cr fractions remained stable from the beginning of the treatment to the 240th d. However, the passivation rate of the 3% CN treatment significantly fluctuated from 73.46% to 63.99%. This indicated that the immobilization effect of CNH had prominent long-term stability. Meanwhile, the soil with all treatments, especially those of CNH treatment, suffered less Cr stress, its micro-ecological level was
ameliorated to comparable to uncontaminated soil, and thus the remediated soil could have durable stability. Consequently, CNH exhibited better remediate ability than CN and HA, which indicated that CNH composite may provide an efficient and enduring method for in situ remediation of Cr contaminated soil.

metadata.abstractText: Remediation of soil chromium (Cr) pollution is becoming more and more urgent. In this study, a multiloaded nano-zero-valent iron (nZVI) material (CNH) was prepared by carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) and humic acid (HA) as dispersant and support agent, respectively, and the remediation effect of CNH, HA and CN (CNH without HA) for Cr contaminated soil was investigated within 90 d cycle. After 7 d treatment of CNH, the HOAc-extractable Cr decreased significantly. After the 90 d remediation, the HOAc-extractable Cr decreased most in the treatment of 3% CNH, about 74.48% lower than control. All treatments eventually caused different decline of soil pH, with a range of 0.12e0.54, in which the CNH treatment group had the least depression. HA loading significantly weakened the toxicity of nZVI, resulting in the higher soil microbial quantity and enzyme activities compared with CN. Additionally, the improvement of soil microecology by CNH and HA was positively correlated with the ratio of application, while CN was negatively correlated (except FDA enzyme activity) with these indexes. These results emphasized the potential of the synthesized CNH as a promising material to remediate Cr contaminated soil. Furthermore, details of possible mechanistic insight into the Cr remediation were carefully discussed. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
